fields.description:
The default behavior in Bamboo is to omit failed builds from reports reports (reports for clover, tests and etc).

We should give users the option to generate reports across all builds, regardless of the outcome.
fields.summary: Give users option to include failed builds while generating reports

fields.description:
Plugins should be (allowed to be) installed in the bamboo-home, not the bamboo-install location. Given the aggressive release schedule of bamboo, upgrades are frequent. But actual API changes (or at least, an API change that might affect a given plugin) are less so.

Remembering to copy over installed plugins is at best an annoyance. And its easy to forget.

If the plugins were loaded from the bamboo-home location, then there would be no need to upgrade them.

For that matter, things like ODBC drivers could be in there, too.
fields.summary: Plugin jars should go in bamboo-home

fields.description:
tested on gdansk.bamboo2.atlassian.com

Following call:
https://gdansk.bamboo2.atlassian.com/api/rest/getBuildResultsDetails.action?auth=AUTH&buildKey=TP-TEST&buildNumber=358
returns invalid xml:
<comment>PL-303 UI with a list of comments as a tree created + VersionedComment.getReplies returns List *<VersionedComment>* from now on</comment>
fields.summary: If comment for commit contains xml tag then api/rest/getBuildResultsDetails.action return invalid XML

fields.description: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMEXT/Bamboo+Tagger+plugin
fields.summary: Package Tagger plug-in with Bamboo

fields.description: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMEXT/Pre-Post+Build+Command+Plugin
fields.summary: Package Pre/Post-Build Command plug-in with Bamboo

fields.description:
When notifying users of build failure success, if the build was the result of a dependency build, currently the IM messages look something like this:

JIRA Studio - Functional tests build 918 has FAILED (1 tests failed)

Emails contain a message like this:

This build occurred because of a dependency build.

The problem with this is it doesn't tell you who broke the build, which kinda defeats the purpose of instant notifications, you want to know who broke the build so they can be blamed, shamed, and start working on fixing it immediately.  So it would be much better if for dependency builds, the root cause of the build (found by recursing through all the parent builds until a non dependency cause was found) was displayed.  Something like this:

JIRA Studio - Functional tests build 918 has FAILED (1 tests failed) Change made to Shared Access Layer - Default by James Roper.

So the message will show not only who broke it, but what project/build they changed.
fields.summary: Notifications should display the root cause of a dependency build

fields.description:
The tests, artifacts and metrics relating to a single repository revision are often spread across one or more trees of dependent builds.

It would be _very_ useful to provide a view of build status and build results from a revision-centric, rather than build-centric, perspective.
fields.summary: Provide a consolidated view of build results per-revision, rather than per-build

fields.description: As GIT is getting more and more popular, a support for GIT is necessary for BAMBOO.
fields.summary: GIT support for BAMBOO

fields.description:
If a user is null i.e: the user exists in cached Bamboo database but has been deleted form LDAP. Bamboo logs that the user as null but, still tries to export the user. 

This causes a nullpointer exception - 
{code}
2008-07-12 01:01:16,336 ERROR [QuartzScheduler_Worker-3] [ScheduledBackupJob] java.lang.NullPointerException
java.lang.NullPointerException
at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.UserMapper.shouldExportUser(UserMapper.java:70)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.UserMapper.exportXml(UserMapper.java:47)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.XmlMigrator.exportXml(XmlMigrator.java:216)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.XmlMigrator$$FastClassByCGLIB$$b6578fc7.invoke(<generated>)
at net.sf.cglib.proxy.MethodProxy.invoke(MethodProxy.java:149)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.Cglib2AopProxy$CglibMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(Cglib2AopProxy.java:694)
at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:149)
at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor.invoke(TransactionInterceptor.java:106){code}
fields.summary: Nullpointer Exception while exporing non-existant users.

fields.summary: Bamboo fails to startup as service in Windows Vista
Strange horizontal scrolling on build results pages

fields.description:
Upgrade the Nant jar to fix this bug - http://developer.atlassian.com/jira/browse/NANT-5

If a user configures a builder on the agent, Bamboo will fail to restart as it tries to validate the path where builder exists.
fields.summary: Upgrade Nant jar

fields.description: Upgrade out xstream library to 1.3 from 1.2.2  due to [this memory leak issue|http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/XSTR-410]
fields.summary: Bamboo fails with OOM error, due to memory leak in xstream library

fields.description:
Not actually sure if this is logically possible, but it would be cool if you could somehow specifically set the broker address on a per agent basis. 

For example on BEAC we had a problems where there were two remote locations which could see 1 entry point into the box bamboo was on, and another remote location which could see another entry point.   These problem was due to security restrictions on the boxes.
fields.summary: Ability to have different broker addresses for different agents

fields.description:
To implement a such new features, one of solution would be to implement a new Scheme.
In this case, it would be a new sample to document the step by step documentation asked in JRA-15225.

Thks
fields.summary: Be able to reference more than one Bamboo from JIRA

fields.description:
There are two main cases here that affect us (that I know of):

1.  The perforce client has a name change.
If the client name has changed and Bamboo tried to run a command against the now non-existant client, perforce will actually create a client for you.  The default for this client is to have the root directory set to the running directory.  This can then lead to weird situations where Bamboo is trying to clear out directories that it shouldn't (see https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-1012 for an example)   

2.  The perforce client has its depot mappings changed
Whilst i can not reproduce this, it is reported that this can actually cause Bamboo to pick up/detect all Perforce changes whether they are related to that build or not.

We need to be a bit more defensive to ensure this does not have any undesirable side effects.
fields.summary: Changes to perforce client spec (without changing Bamboo) can cause odd behaviour

fields.description:
see CWD-1167 for details.

We just need to document it so users can fix it up themselves
fields.summary: Bamboo integration with crowd doesnt play nicely with caches.
Users should be able to reset plan build numbers via the UI

fields.description:
When your license expired, Bamboo will redirect you to the license update page {{e.g. http://localhost:8095/admin/updateLicense!default.action}}. After submitting a new valid license, however, it'll still redirect you to the same screen. 

We should simply redirect them to the app.
fields.summary: Updating an expired license redirects you to the license page

fields.description: As per BSP-1015, moving massive logs over WAN can be very slow - we need to improve our current mechanism for quicker log transfer.
fields.summary: Improve log transfer between Bamboo agent and build server

fields.description: We need a way to launch virtual machines with a Bamboo Agent present before we queue a build.
fields.summary: Add Pre-Build-queued action plugin point

fields.description:
There have been several reported cases of people losing data due to Bamboo's deleting build directory for the force clean build option.  

Having another think about it, I really think we need to separate out the logic for deletion of the build directory to be the responsibility of each of the individual repositories. 

In particular the Perforce repository should be deleting the folder defined in the workspace mapping not the entire root (which is required for svn and cvs).  I imagine it would be common to have the root set to a directory which has other stuff in it.
fields.summary: Better Logic for deletion of build directory (for force clean build)

fields.description: Currently performing a force build will delete all files in the working directory, if the perforce root is pointed to a system folder, i.e "/" or "C:\Windows" directory - Bamboo will clean out these folders to perform a clean build.
fields.summary: Warn users, they shouldn't point their perforce root directory to system folders.

fields.description: Users should be able to timeout builds if they are taking too long
fields.summary: Time out builds if they are taking too long

fields.description:
I've currently got 50+ plans in our Bamboo, and once it's rolled out to the whole company that will probably treble.
This makes the current _Build Status Summary_ Jira plugin pretty much unusable.

I'd like to be able to restrict the buid status to a single project, so only the plans in that project will appear on my dashboard.
(Our development teams will probably only care about one or two projects each).
fields.summary: Per project build status summary

fields.description:
On the live activity screen, the selected text is cleared every time the reload occurs even if the content hasn't changed.

We should only clear the selection if the content has changed
fields.summary: Cannot select any test on the live activity screen
Failure message not displayed for junit 4 assertEquals test results
Passwords submitted REST API login method are logged by AccessLogFilter

fields.description:
Perforce manages which changes/files you have by storing the information on the server.  Once you have downloaded the change A with one client it marks that change as being downloaded.  If you then use that same client on another machine the Perforce Server will assume you already have change A and not download it. 

This means that using perforce on multiple build agents won't pick up the changes when it syncs. So it could be building incorrect code.

Because of this you have a few options.

# Restrict your plan to use a single machine and (if using multiple agents on the one machine, also set the client root yourself).
# Make Bamboo force a clean build every time it builds (okay for smaller projects but a pain for larger ones)
# Use alternate roots  This would allow you to restrict your plan to 3 machines with 3 different alternate roots (a slightly better alternative than #1).  A word of warning though, Bamboo will go through the roots in order till one exists so if you want Bamboo to build in the third root the first two must not exist on that machine.
fields.summary: Perforce Building on Multiple Agents Doesn't Detect Changes Correctly
The REST API should be extended to return project/plan dependencies structures.

fields.summary: The shipped Bamboo 2.0.5 source code doesn't compile

fields.description:
In certain cases, (combinations of file moves, removes. additions) SVN can get in state where an update will fail. In such circumstances, all subsequent updates will fail. Bamboo should be able to detect these and do an automatic cleanup for the user.

Error 1: object of the same name already exists
{noformat}
Caused by: org.tmatesoft.svn.core.SVNException: svn: Failed to add file 'subprojects/func_tests/src/etc/java/bamboo-config/branch/standard/jdk1.4/bamboo.containers.properties': object of the same name already exists
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc.SVNErrorManager.error(SVNErrorManager.java:55)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc.SVNErrorManager.error(SVNErrorManager.java:40)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.http.HTTPConnection.request(HTTPConnection.java:534)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.http.HTTPConnection.request(HTTPConnection.java:245)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.http.HTTPConnection.request(HTTPConnection.java:233)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVConnection.doReport(DAVConnection.java:219)

	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVRepository.update(DAVRepository.java:610)

	at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SvnRepository.update(SvnRepository.java:615)

fields.summary: Auto detection of SVN problems which requires a clean

fields.description:
From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-1006
{quote}
We have multiple Plans / Projects that have common code that can be shared between them. In order to be space efficient, I would like to setup the usage of the structure whereby we can have multiple plans / projects in a structure, yet still share common code without having to have that common code "checked out" into each plan / project baseline. An example of this structure would be as follows:

Current structure used by Bamboo and Plan / Project "PlanA":

/Bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir
===> /PlanA
======> /PlanA_SRC
======>/Shared_modules

Now, if I bring a second Plan / Project "Planb" into the picture that also uses the shared_modules:

/Bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir
===>/PlanA
======>/PlanA_SRC
======>/Shared_modules
===> /PlanB
======>/PlanB_SRC
======>/Shared_modules

What I would like to see is the ability to setup the Bamboo-home structure whereby it uses our Shared_modules as a coomon code shared between Plans / projects
{quote}
fields.summary: Allow sharing of local working directory between plans.

fields.description:
Instead of tuning build expiry to remove builds after X weeks, can we just say - remove old artifacts when they reach a certain limit.  All I care about is that my disk does not get full.
The risk with this method is that one extremely large artifact could blow away all other artifacts.
fields.summary: Limit build artifact archiving to a certain percentage of disk space

fields.description: As archiving our build artifacts are limited by disk space, it would be nice to give some kind of indication how much room would be saved by changing expiry options.
fields.summary: Auto Expire should indicate how much more space changing settings will give you

fields.description:

Even though the main Ant build failed with the BUILD FAILED message, Bamboo assumed that the Ant build passed because there was a BUILD SUCCESSFUL message printed out by the exec task. See build log below -

fields.summary: Bamboo should look for the BUILD FAILED message along with the BUILD SUCCESSFUL message to determine build out come.

fields.description:
Currently, the AbstractBuilder class is hard coded to use the AntJunitTestReportCollector for it's parsing of test results, which means that test results either need to be in the JUnit report format, or a test report-specific Builder plugin must be developed to parse non-JUnit report formats.

It would be nice if the test report format could be specified on the Builder configuration, so that support for other testing formats could be added without the extra overhead of creating a entire new plugin.  Perhaps the test report parsing logic could be factored out into a plugin type of it's own?
fields.summary: Add ability to plug specific test report parsing capabilities into Builder

fields.description: An Eclipse-Plugin for aministrating and monitoring the builds would be great. Ideally this plugin can mange user-accounts and build-plans. The Plugin should be able to display the statistics-page for every build and the whole plan. It should be possible to start builds manually from eclipse and there should be a notification mechanism (may be like mylyn).
fields.summary: Eclipse Plugin

fields.description:
If a local agent goes down due to an error, it will remain down and it will not be possible to restart it. 

We need to better log this and also manually restart the agent.
fields.summary: Local agents that goes down cannot be restarted

fields.description:
The Perforce library we're using stores the entire output of each command regardless of whether or not it's used. Moreover, after each command is run a call to {{StringBuilder.toString}} is called, which effectively clones the entire String array, doubling the memory required for that time.

We should rework the logging so that such excess memory is not required, and for the sync command, not even need to have a copy of the logs in memory.
fields.summary: Perforce sync command is memory inefficient

fields.description:
At the moment remote agents times out after not being able to contact the server for 15s. This happens quite regularly when load on the agent is high.

To fix this issue, we're increasing the thread priority of the heartbeat, increasing the default timeout and also making this value configurable.
fields.summary: Agents timeout too frequently

fields.description: It would be great if people using CruiseControl (or Hudson for that matter) could kickstart their Bamboo evaluation with their existing config. Obviously it won't be a one-to-one but anything that could be reused would be a big win.
fields.summary: Import Config from CruiseControl

fields.description: It will be useful, if we had a "report this error" link whenever Bamboo server failed with a 500 error.
fields.summary: Bamboo should let users report errors when there is a 500 internal server error.

fields.description: Since they are verbs VS nouns
fields.summary: Change Login -> Log in and Logout -> Log out

fields.description: Since 2.0 we can now change detect without local source code. We should make sure take advantage of this by actually exporting the lastVcsKey
fields.summary: Bamboo shouldn't need to immediately re-checkout code after import

fields.description:
See attachment.

The list of file changes doesn't seem to be correct also.
fields.summary: Bamboo says that a build was a result of changes despite being manually triggered

fields.description: Some people have configured Bamboo to do builds whenever a change is detected, but for the rest of us it could be quite useful to be able to see what changes (or how many, at a higher level) have been made since the last build.
fields.summary: Show outstanding/unbuilt changes

fields.description: After creating a new plan with the REST API (BAM-2630), I would then like to be able to retrieve all of the details of how a plan is configured via the REST API.
fields.summary: Ability to retrieve Plan configuration via REST remote API

fields.description:
If a build is being built, Bamboo will ignore build trigger and not queue the build.

In case of a dependent test build, you might want plan to built for each trigger -
{quote}Bear in mind that the code can successfully build, but still fail testing. Thus the following readily occurs:

    * code changes => plan A runs
    * plan A completes => plan B runs
    * code changes again => plan A runs
    * plan A completes, plan B still running => plan B not queued
    * plan B completes
{quote}
fields.summary: Bamboo should queue dependent builds, even when the dependent build is building
Bamboo should report clover-check failure message rather than "possible compilation error" when coverage check fails

fields.description: We should catch the exception so that the agent thread doesn't die.
fields.summary: Errors causes agents to stop
The live logs page doesn't show any text.

fields.description: If a plan is being built and the remote agent goes dies, the "All Plans" tab on dashboard indicates agent as still building (the circle icon indicates the plan as being built) - however, the plan has actually stopped building and I can see that the plan is no longer queued in "Current Activity" tab.
fields.summary: Errors on local agent do not get reported

fields.description:
We need a way to allow users to supply remote agent capabilities at the time the remote agent is started for the first time.

This should be done using system properties, as the remote agent bootstrap should not be directly dependent on this feature.
fields.summary: A mechanism to allow remote agent capabilities to be supplied on start-up
"Triggered" is spelt incorrectly

fields.description:
Someone kicked off a reindex of our Bamboo install today (locking everyone out for an hour), and I don't have any request logs available to see who it was.

What I'd like to have is a daily rolling request log with 5 days of history in {{$BAMBOO_HOME/logs}} so I can review accesses to Bamboo.
I'd prefer not to have to sort through the standard Log4J logs to find these, but rather have them in a separate file.
Having this enabled by default, or managed as a configuration option in the Bamboo configuration is important - I don't want this to drop out when I forget to hack {{log4j.properties}} during the next upgrade.

Something like what Jetty produces as per [http://docs.codehaus.org/display/JETTY/Logging+Requests] would work for me.

(I can see there's an AccessLogFilter and I've actually enabled that for now, but it's not documented and not ideal so I'm assuming a feature request will stand).
fields.summary: Request logging

fields.description:
Bamboo has a l{{og4j.properties}} file set up to log all messages to a ConsoleAppender and a RollingFileAppender

In the former case they get logged to the wrapper log in {{$BAMBOO_HOME/logs}}, and in the latter case dumped in whatever directory {{wrapper}} is run in (since the path for the log file isn't set in {{log4j.properties}.
Currently this means I have to give my build user write permissions to the {{wrapper}} directory, which I'm not overjoyed about.

What I'd like to see is:
* A single RollingFileAppender (actually I'd prefer a DailyRollingFileAppender to make finding logs easier)
* All log files in $BAMBOO_HOME/logs - e.g. {{wrapper.log}} and {{atlassian-bamboo.log}}
* No ConsoleAppender
* BAM-2803 fixed so I don't get remote agent spam in my logs
fields.summary: Default log setup duplicates logs to file and console appenders

fields.description:
Currently in my Bamboo log, I get one log statement at the INFO level for every remote agent I have (7 now, potentially 20) every second telling me that the agent is being updated - I assume this means it's pinging the agent.

I'd like not to see these messages at INFO - perhaps DEBUG - and just see WARNs when agents drop out.
fields.summary: Reduced log spam from remote agents

fields.description:
Reported in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-971 -

{quote}
Many of our builds check out from subversion repositories that have symlinks in them, usually something like library.jar pointing to a file that is a specific version library-x.y.jar. An engineer may update the library by doing the following all in one commit:

svn rm library-1.2.jar
svn add library-1.3.jar
ln -sf library-1.3.jar library.jar
svn commit
{quote}

SVNKit support confirmed this to be a bug, and said it would be fixed in 1.1.8 release. We need to upgrade to SVNKit 1.1.8 once released.
fields.summary: SVNKit fails to upgrade source code, if there are any modified symlinks.

fields.description:
CCTray is a Windows application that adds an icon to your system tray.  It connects to your CruiseControl.NET server(s) and shows green if everything has built properly, red if something failed to build.

I'm pushing to switch our team from CruiseControl.NET to Bamboo.  One of the guys on my team is completely stuck on CCTray.  Does Bamboo have an equivalent (ideally in Java or something cross platform) available or scheduled?  If not, can you point me to APIs I might be able to use to make my own (if absolutely necessary)?

Thanks,

Vince
fields.summary: CCTray for Bamboo?

fields.description:
When importing a large file during setup (and probably through the administration page as well), the browser will time out.

We should serve an progress page that refreshes instead.
fields.summary: Browser timeout during import

fields.description:
You quite often would like to stop a build you know that's going to fail without spamming all and sundry that the build has failed, nor do you want to save that particular build.

There should be another option which to a Stop and Adbandon the running build and it'll be treated like it was never kicked off in the first place.
fields.summary: Ability to abandon a build

fields.description:
We have a Bamboo build farm consisting of a core set of Linux build servers, which most builds run on, and a set of platform build servers for building native binaries. 
Some of these platform build servers aren't appropriate for building all our builds (mainly because of capacity issues).

e.g. we have:

build (3 local agents)
build2 (3 remote agents)
build-win (1 remote agent)
build-aix (1 remote agent)
build-hpux (1 remote agent)
etc. (we'll have 7 remote native platform build servers once we've set them all up)

Currently the only way we have of preventing an arbitrary build from building on any of the remote machines is to change the names of the capabilities on each of them, which means we've got a big list of {{Ant 1.6 (Windows)}} {{Ant 1.6 (AIX)}}, {{Ant 1.6 (HPUX-PARISC)}} etc. builders.

What we'd like is the ability to declare on an agent that only build plans labelled as (for example) {{Windows native build}} and configure the agents to only build plans that declare that attribute.

There's some similarity in this scenario with being able to expedite builds through the build queue (e.g. a high priority plan or build can be given exclusivity or precedence on certain agents).
fields.summary: Permit builds on agents based on build plan attributes

fields.description: Provide an option to select the JIRA Project Component Lead within the Bamboo notification scheme.
fields.summary: Allow selection of JIRA Project Lead for Notification if integrated

fields.description: Improves performance of quite a few things, including the build expiry
fields.summary: Move artifactLinks to the database
Bamboo gets confused when passing in quoted system environment variables

fields.description:
See BAM-2781 for an example.

When the server performs a heartbeat check, it should take the last time it was able to perform a check into account.
fields.summary: Server side of heartbeat mechanism is sensitive to thread starvation

fields.description: In my organization, the bamboo server is 'community property' owned by the IT department, but the remote agents are 'owned' by the projects.  IT doesn't want to foot the bill for disk storage or CPU power to support all the builds, also, they don't want each project to buy and stand up their own Bamboo servers. One solution would be to have the large build artifacts remain on the remote agents, and have the server link to them using standard HTTP redirects.
fields.summary: Ability ti leave/link build artifacts on remote agents

fields.description:
We have a project setup which is very modularized and re-uses many modules for many build plans.

Example:
*Build Plan A*
{noformat}
common.jar
repository.jar
applicationA.jar (<- depends on common.jar and repository.jar)
{noformat}

All three modules are required in order to generate applicationA.

*Build Plan B*
{noformat}
common
applicationB (<-- depends on common.jar only)
{noformat}

applicationB requires common as well but is different otherwise.

The problem is now, that maven's pom files manage the dependencies and thus we manage the pom file for each module.
Bamboo however, requires as a first step to checkout the required modules up front and then starts building using maven.
To use Bamboo nevertheless, we're currently using Subversion externals - which basically works fine, but in essence is a duplication of the same information already present in the pom's dependency section.

Again and again it is a problem when new dependencies are added or changed, because developers think about the dependency in the pom file, but not in subversion's svn:externals (not talking about the fact, that svn:externals are quite tricky to manage without checking out all of the modules all the time).

Maven has an answer to this problem: scm:checkout can get all the code including the according dependencies and start building afterwards.
We would love to use this approach, but currently can't due to the Bamboo restriction.

Is there anything in planning to resolve this?
Have you got any other suggestion / best practise available for such cases?

Thanks
Kay
fields.summary: Cannot use maven (scm:checkout) instead of standard subversion checkout

fields.description:
Using our standard Bamboo settings I can't connect using the Bamboo CLI from a remote machine, I get the following exception:

org.swift.common.cli.CliClient$ClientException: Error - invalid request: java.rmi.RemoteException:         Access is denied

When I run from a shell on the Bamboo server itself I get a different exception:

org.swift.common.cli.CliClient$ClientException: Error - invalid request: java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused

When I turn on anonymous access the command succeeds. I did some searches and found this bug:

http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-799

It was mentioned in this forum post:

http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257241794&#257241794

Here's the relevant post:

"Do you have anonymous access turned off? If it is, do you want to try your scenarios with it turned on (i.e. non-logged in users can hit Bamboo).

I think the reason you are being redirected is because of the security filter for anonymous access. This filter should not happen with REST api calls. I have raised a bug in JIRA about this - apologies about this. http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-799"

I'm not being redirected to the login page, but allowing or disallowing anonymous users shouldn't have any effect on this call should it? The account I'm trying to connect with is in the bamboo-admin group. I've tried with a different account that is also part of the bamboo-admin group, no dice on that one either.

Am I doing something wrong, or does this just not work unless anonymous access is turned on?
fields.summary: The Bamboo CLI doesn't work unless anonymous access is enabled

fields.description: We need to commit changes by calling connection.commi() or else the changes are not commited.
fields.summary: Bamboo Pre-hibernate Upgrade tasks fail in 2.0.4, for postgresql

fields.description:
There is a known issue with perforce and distributed builds where changes are not applied correctly to each agent.  The Perforce server keeps record of which changes you have received so once you have downloaded them on one box, Perforce will assume you have them even though the next build may be on another box.

The first alternative for nice distributed build systems is the Alternate Roots, however these can  not be managed by Bamboo and only allows for 3 roots.

It would be nice if we could somehow manage this better for the user

Suggestion 1:  Bamboo takes in all the information required to CREATE a client during plan configuration.  When it builds, it would create a Perforce Client based on the template given in the configuration fro that machine, thus you would have a client per machine and changes would be picked up properly
Possible Problems: 
* Any updates the the plan configuration would have to be reflected in the created clients
* Permissioning could be an issue.  The Bamboo uses would require special permissions to be able to create clients.  Also  the create clients need the correct permissions set.  
* If an agent gets removed the client either needs to be removed by Bamboo (difficult to manage) or you can end up with 'rogue' clients left over.
* There may be client number limits on the Perforce Server.

Suggestion 2: The User creates all the required clients (one for each machine) and somehow tells Bamboo which client to use on which agent.  However this is not a preferable situation.  It would be extremely painful for the user to setup and maintain
fields.summary: Better management of perforce clients on multiple build agents.

fields.description: BuildReults are partially stored in xStreamed as well as the database.  This can lead to inconsistent states in the data and thanks to  BAM-2772, also can be a performance bottleneck.
fields.summary: Dcprecate / remove buildresultsNNN.xml

fields.description:
TestResults are still stored in the BuildResults object. This makes dealing with them difficult, and causes performance problems when test result sets are large. 

They should be stored in the dB
fields.summary: MIgrate test results from xStream

fields.description:
Some properties we have defined as Global Variables and then referring to them like -Dproperty1.name=${bamboo.property1.name} -Dproperty2.name=${bamboo.property2.name} and so on. 

Regarding specification of Global Variables I have two remarks, the first is that it is not possible to edit a variable, but it must instead be deleted and added anew. 

The second remark is regarding the ordering of the specified Global Variables. Currently it seems to be some hash map order or similar. It would be nice to be able to sort the global variables, or at least to have them in alphabetical order or maybe the order the were added in.
fields.summary: Ability to Edit & Sort Global Variables

fields.description:
Exports from instances of Bamboo using an Oracle database fail, with the following error message:

bq. Export has failed. Errors encountered while exporting. Adding text to an XML document must not be null

The following exception appears in the bamboo.log:

{noformat}

 java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Adding text to an XML document must not be null

{noformat}

fields.description:
We occasionally get empty notification emails from bamboo. All they have in them is the subject '[Bamboo]'. The logged errors are below.  It doesn't happen every time, maybe 1 in 5 or so.

This started happening when we upgraded from v1.2.2 to v2.0.3. I did an export of 1.2.2, then created a new bamboo home and database for v2.0.3 to use then imported the previous export. The version of the database and jdbc driver stayed the same.

Mark.

fields.description:
Bamboo currently caches the entire Buidresults object when user tries to view a buildresult - in case of Bamboo instances, where the builds produce huge amounts of tests the cache eventually results in OOM error.

We should make the cache configurable, so that Bamboo doesn't run out of memory.

Originally reported in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-927
fields.summary: Bamboo runs out of memory if the buildresults have too many tests.

fields.description:
When "Let Bamboo manage your workspace' is turned off, but it has been running for a while, Bamboo should revert the client root in the Perforce clientspec to the original value, or warn the user that they must do this.

I was testing Bamboo's ability to manage the workspace - while I found it to be quite useful in general, we can't use it in our specific case.  When I reverted the setting, the test builds no longer worked.  It took me a while to diagnose the cause of the "com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException : Unable to extract client root from Perforce, therefore could not evaluate where the source will be checked out to" errors I was getting.    

Naturally this was corrected by changing the value of the clientspec root.  It would be nice for Bamboo to be able to revert this for the user, or at the very least provide a prompt to indicate that is must be done.
fields.summary: Bamboo should revert clientspec root when "Let Bamboo Manage your Workspace" is turned off

fields.description:
Originally reported in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-934 and a quick googling returned [this SVNKit bug report|http://svnkit.com/tracker/view.php?id=241].

Apparently, its planned for fix in SVNKit 1.2! 

Workaround - If this is a major issue then, customers can try the SVNKit nightly builds
fields.summary: SVNKit doesn't 1.1.7 support http.nonProxyHosts

fields.description:
To reproduce:
* Configure a remote agent - auto-detects all JDKs and Ants present on the server
* Delete the JDKs/Ants you don't want
* Add a new JDK/Ant
* Stop and restart remote agent
*Expected Outcome:*
Remote agent has the same capabilities when it starts back up again as it did before it was shut down
*Actual Outcome:*
Remote agent has the JDKs/Ants that were added, but also re-detects all the JDKs/Ants that were previously deleted

It would be nice to not have to re-configure all my remote agents' capabilities everytime they get restarted for whatever reason.
fields.summary: Remote Agent detects previously deleted capabilities after restart

fields.description: When setting up a second remote agent on the same remote server (Windows), Bamboo didn't correctly detect all the JDKs and Ants on the server.  It detected all the JREs on the server ([BAM-2756]), but not the JDK that was installed.  It also didn't detect an instance of Ant (1.7).  The JDK and Ant it failed to detect was successfully detected by the first remote agent from that same server.
fields.summary: Second Remote Agent on same server doesn't correctly detect JDK + Ant

fields.description: When configuring a remote agent on a Windows box, Bamboo auto-detected the Ants/JDKs available on the server.  However it auto-detected several JREs as JDKs.
fields.summary: Remote Agent detects JRE as JDK

fields.description:
When viewing the Activity tab for a plan in Firefox (at least 2 and 3), the Ant output in the log is triple spaced.

Specifically you get a pattern like:

{noformat}
13-Jun-2008 10:17:52 	     
                                            [exec] Embedding manifest...

13-Jun-2008 10:17:52 	     
                                            [exec] Build log was saved at "file://c:\Build\Tools\Bamboo 2.0 Remote Agent 1\xml-da <snip>

13-Jun-2008 10:17:52 	     
                                            [exec] isapi - 0 error(s), 13 warning(s)

13-Jun-2008 10:17:52 	     
                                            [exec] ========== Rebuild All: 3 succeeded, 0 failed, 0 skipped ==========

{noformat}
e.g. there's a blank line inserted above and below any line of output in the display.

When the same log is viewed in the results for that build, it is displayed with no extra lines.
fields.summary: Ant output in Activity log is triple spaced in Firefox

fields.description:
We're trying to set up a Remote Agent, and for some of our builds we need to change the paths of executables used.  Capabilities seem like a nice way to do this, but variable substitution seems horribly broken.  

The following log details the problem in a test build where we are attempting to use the Ruby executable in a script builder, using capability variables to define where Ruby is:

12-Jun-2008 15:03:03  	 Executing build BAMBOO-TEST-3
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03 	Running pre-build action: Build Number Stamper
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03 	Running pre-build action: VCS Version Collector
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03 	Building started with ScriptBuilder
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03 	Starting to build 'Build System Testing - Ruby Capability Testing'
... running command line: ${bamboo.capability.Ruby} puts test
... in : E:\bamboo-home\xml-data\build-dir\BAMBOO-TEST\integration\.\BambooTools
... using java: null
... using environment variables:
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03 	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.capability.Ruby} with c:\ruby\bin\ruby.exe
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03  	Failed to execute build: Cannot find executable at ${bamboo.capability.Ruby}

Notice that the variable substitution "works" per this line:
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03 	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.capability.Ruby} with c:\ruby\bin\ruby.exe

Immediately after we see the following:
12-Jun-2008 15:03:03  	 Failed to execute build: Cannot find executable at ${bamboo.capability.Ruby}

If I replace the "${bamboo.capability.Ruby" with "c:\ruby\bin\ruby.exe" it works just fine.

We cannot use a build agent effectively, if we cannot resolve problems like this.
fields.summary: Script builder and capability variable substitution appear broken

fields.description:
We use Outlook for email, and it's nice to be able to have the email that comes in with the high priority flag set on when a build/test fails.  However, I'd recommend making this a global option that only the admin can change for the whole site.

(If I'm not mistaken there's a X-Priority in the header that can be setup.)

Thanks
fields.summary: Have an option to make failed builds/tests emails be set with a "high priority" flag

fields.description:
Slow agent start-up times would probably be more tolerable if agents were more vocal about what they were doing during the startup process.  Continued status updates would go a long way to curing user anxiety over the agent startup.


As best I can tell all you get on agent startup is a line like the following on the Agents administration page:

Jun 12, 2008 9:37:54 AM A remote agent is loading on elided<host> (elided<address>).

If this line refreshed to inform me what was going on, I wouldn't mind the wait.  ETAs are nice too.

As it is, I'm not sure if the agent is dead or not the way this currently works.
fields.summary: Agents should report startup progress

fields.description:
BAM-2296 updated the SVNKit used in Bamboo to 1.1.7, however the [JNA|https://jna.dev.java.net/] native library toolkit was not included.
As a result, Subversion checkouts on Linux still run a massive amount of {{ls}} commands during the checkout of a large source tree, resulting in a serious impact on server performance  (BAM-2296 has a summary, but it's on the order of 50% of the CPU on a 4 core box).

I've manually added jna.jar to Bamboo 2.0.4 and this fixes the problem on the server, but it causes checkouts on remote agents (in this case running on Windows) to fail (A NotImplementedException in the AgentClassLoader).

What I'd like is for JNA to be used by SVNKit on all [supported platforms|https://jna.dev.java.net/#building], including Local and Remote agents.
fields.summary: JNA based native library optimisations for SVNKit

fields.description:
When running TestNG tests, bamboo fails to parse the testng-results.xml file and instead draws all test results from TEST-TestSuite.xml. Although it appears that no information is missing, we should investigate to see if there is something important we are missing out on or if we could benefit from using of the information in this file.

We also need to stop throwing an exception when this occurs. http://pastebin.com/m26a1a114
fields.summary: Excessive error loggging when does not parse testng-results.xml correctly
Update version of Jira Soap Client Bamboo Uses

fields.description: Our normal build returns about 174 MB of artifacts in over 8000 files (the wisdom of this is another issue). When we run this build remotely, we've consistently gotten an error on the server about the remote agent going offline as the artifacts are being copied. Reducing the number of artifacts alleviates the problem. My guess is that while the artifacts are being transferred, the heartbeat isn't maintained.
fields.summary: Returning large amount of artifacts from remote agent results in agent being offline on server

fields.description:
I have Bamboo 2.0 setup with LDAP integration with Active Directory. We have a setup along the lines of:

    * GroupA
          o GroupB
                + UserA
                + UserB
          o GroupC
                + UserC


It would be nice to give all users in Group A access to Bamboo but that doesn't appear to work. I have to explicitly give Groups B and C access in the global permissions configuration for any of the users in those groups to have access to Bamboo. Have I missed some configuration option somewhere or is there an option I can set in the atlassian-user.xml to enable Bamboo to include users with a Group depth of more than 1? Or is this simply not possible and I should just explicitly add each of the sub-groups?

From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257282143#257282143
fields.summary: Bamboo should support nested group permissioning

fields.description: If the local username and the Alias usernames match - Bamboo should just assign the user the alias.
fields.summary: Bamboo should automatically assign users, to their Source Repository Alias

fields.description:
If an LDAP user is removed from the repository before to deleting him from a local Bamboo group (eg: Bamboo-Admin) then the operation fails with 
{code}
Build: 801
Build Date: Apr 14, 2008

Stack Trace:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: User unknown: [null] in [hibernateRepository]
at com.atlassian.user.impl.hibernate.HibernateGroupManager.validateGroupAndUser(HibernateGroupManager.java:457)
at com.atlassian.user.impl.hibernate.HibernateGroupManager.removeMembership(HibernateGroupManager.java:479)
at com.atlassian.user.impl.delegation.DelegatingGroupManagerTemplate.removeMembership(DelegatingGroupManagerTemplate.java:211)
at bucket.user.DefaultUserAccessor.removeMembership(DefaultUserAccessor.java:532)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.user.BambooUserManagerImpl.setMembership(BambooUserManagerImpl.java:330){code}

We should make sure that, as long as LDAP user belongs to a local Bamboo group - he can be deleted from the group (regardless of whether or not he exists in the LDAP repository.)

Reported in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-840
fields.summary: LDAP user can't be removed from group(s), if the user doesn't exist in LDAP repository.

fields.description: Document how to move Bamboo-agent-home.
fields.summary: Document how to move Bamboo-agent-home

fields.description:
We can have a problem when

# Agent 1 takes Build A-1 from Plan A
# Agent 1 loses network connectivity to the server
# Agent 1 is marked as "going down" and goes off-line since the server could not receive the heartbeat. Lock on Plan A is  released
# Build A-2 is triggered. Starts building on Local Agent
# Agent 1 comes back online, still with Build A-1.

At this point, things go wrong. Logs gets streamed in a funny way (since we assume that only one build is ever building), Build A-2 is saved with Build A-1. JIRAns have an example of this.

We should make sure if an agent has been marked as going offline, it is never allowed of come back (maybe check startup timestamp) when an Agent comes back online.

Needs further investigation and if the problem is too large to safely fix on branch, then we can defer it to fixing on trunk.
fields.summary: Remote agents may return even when already marked as dead

fields.description:
Currently the Bamboo Linux standalone has 2 sources of config, the wrapper.conf file and the bamboo.sh script.

We should look consolidating the two config files, so that Bamboo always reads from just one config file. 

This caused  https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-901, where customer updated the wrapper.conf file instead of the bamboo.sh script
fields.summary: Simplify the Bamboo install process

fields.description: When multiple builds fail in a row, successive failure notifications show the names of committers in the checkins since the last build. We'd like to be able to feature the user who was responsible for the original breakage in the subject line and at the top of the email. This could be implemented as a setting or email template editor of some sort. I couldn't find anything like that in the current version of Bamboo.
fields.summary: I'd like to be able to edit the build failure notifications that are sent out.

fields.description: When the bamboo remote agents wants to clean the build working directory, it fails saying that it can't remove a certain file. Further analysis points out that this file is actually a symbolic link which points to a file that isn't there.
fields.summary: Bamboo remote agent can't clean up broken symbolic links
